title: Craig Gillies
text:
Craig Gillies (born 6 May 1976) is a former <a href="England">English</a> <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player. His final club was <a href="Worcester%20Warriors">Worcester Warriors</a> in the <a href="Aviva%20Premiership">Aviva Premiership</a>. He played as a <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%234.%20.26%205.%20Lock">lock</a>.
Gillies was born in <a href="Paisley%2C%20Renfrewshire">Paisley</a> and grew up in <a href="Tiverton%2C%20Devon">Tiverton</a>, <a href="Devon">Devon</a>. He joined <a href="Bath%20Rugby">Bath Rugby</a> following a trial in April 1994 and made three first team appearances during the 1995–1996 season. He moved on to join <a href="Richmond%20F.C.">Richmond</a> for the 1997–1998 season with the then Bath coach <a href="Andy%20Robinson">Andy Robinson</a> feeling that the club's signing of the <a href="Argentina%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Argentinian</a> international German Llanes would prevent Gillies from getting the sufficient game time to allow him to fully develop his potential. Gillies moved on to join <a href="Scarlets">Llanelli</a> before signing for <a href="Gloucester%20Rugby">Gloucester</a> in 2001/02 and then <a href="Worcester%20Warriors">Warriors</a> in the summer of 2002. Whilst at Gloucester he was a replacement in the <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20English%20Premiership%20%28rugby%20union%29">2002 Zurich Championship Final</a> (the year before winning the play-offs constituted winning the English title) in which Gloucester defeated <a href="Bristol%20Bears">Bristol</a>.
Gillies - who is the leading appearance maker at Worcester in the modern era after beating the previous record of 222 held by Tony Windo - was a key part of the unbeaten <a href="National%20Division%20One">National Division One</a> promotion winning team of 2003/04.
The giant lock is widely regarded as one of the best line-out takers in the top-flight and won England A honours in 2000.
A leading figure both on and off the field, Gillies made twenty-nine appearances during the 2009/10 campaign – more than any other Warrior.
Gillies excelled again for Warriors in the <a href="RFU%20Championship">RFU Championship</a> during 2010/11, making twenty-eight appearances to cement a key role in the pack
The second row agreed a new two-year deal in 2011 and is keen to continue to dominate the airwaves for Warriors.
He retired from Rugby in 2013. 
Gillies lost all his body hair to <a href="alopecia">alopecia</a> in 2002.
